urn:contentItem:6DS1-FFM3-RV0F-802G-00000-00A lounge filled with joeys: Wildlife rescuers brace for influx of animals injured in Grampians blaze2024-12-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:24ZLexisNexisA lounge filled with joeys: Wildlife rescuers brace for influx of animals injured in Grampians blazeAlex Crowe

Twenty joeys found refuge from the Boxing Day fire conditions inside the home of a shelter operator.

Wildwood Wildlife Shelter operator Pam Turner wasn't going anywhere on Boxing Day despite her fears the Grampians bushfire could head her way - she had a lounge room with 20 joeys in it to look after.

She and the rescued roos sheltered inside her Victoria Valley house as sprinklers doused the roof and sheds outside.

"I was extremely anxious. I was preparing myself for a giant fireball to come over the mountains," Turner said. "I chose to stay for the very reason that I had a cottage full of joeys. How could I leave them locked in the cottage?"

The forecast 70-kilometre northeasterly winds that threatened to blow the fire towards Wildwood failed to eventuate, and rainfall on Saturday brought some relief to the shelter.

But Turner remains worried about what may be yet to come.

Three homes in the town of Moyston and 11 outbuildings in the surrounding area have been reported as destroyed by the Grampians blaze so far, and animal rescuers are waiting for permission to enter the Grampians National Park to assess wildlife losses.

The blaze, whose perimeter stretches more than 380 kilometres, has scorched more than 75,000 hectares and is expected to burn into the new year due to dry conditions and difficult, mountainous terrain.

Authorities have reported stock losses, as well as beehive, fencing, pasture and hay losses from the fire, which began early last week.

Turner was part of the wildlife rescue effort following the Mount Lubra fire, which burnt half the Grampians in 2006. She said the loss of life had left her traumatised.

"For months afterwards we were finding injured kangaroos, burnt on the pads of their feet. They were starving because there was no food," she said. "At this stage, we don't know what to expect - [the current fire] will certainly be ongoing for weeks and weeks."

An officer from the Environment Department was deployed to assess wildlife losses outside the fire zone this week and was expected to determine whether a triage centre was required to treat injured animals in coming days.

Link to Image

Justin McManus

Wildlife Victoria has experienced an increase in calls about heat-stressed animals since summer began and expected calls for burns and dehydration to spike as people returned to the Grampians.

Residents of Halls Gap were given permission to return to their homes on Friday, but the park remained closed to tourists.

McKenzie Creek resident Brendan Stemp was on alert for changes to weather conditions that could blow embers towards his cattery and neighbouring farmland.

Stemp said the more than 30 cats at his property had been kept comfortable during the worst fire conditions, but he was expecting significant damage to wildlife inside the park.

"Because it's such a huge area, there's millions of animals in there, and all these other critters and insects that the fire's going to take a huge toll on," he said.

Stemp said the other concern was wildlife being pushed out into grazing land and having to compete with sheep and cattle for food.

"Often wildlife come off second best when that happens."

Link to Image

Justin McManus

Cooler conditions in the Wimmera at the weekend are forecast to be replaced by warmer weather next week. The Bureau of Meteorology has predicted temperatures in the low 30s on Monday and up to 35 degrees on Tuesday.

Emergency Management Commissioner Rick Nugent said the next week would provide favourable conditions for firefighters.

"Weather over the next week looks relatively stable. This will allow us time to stabilise the fires and continue back-burning operations, and look to support the community further," Nugent said.

In addition to state and federal support for local government areas affected by the Grampians fire, personal hardship payments are now available. One-off payments of $680 for adults and $340 for children up to $2380 per affected family are being provided to help cover essentials.

Forest Fire Management Victoria spokesman Chris Hardman said it was thanks to firefighters that the fire situation had not been worse in recent days.

"Without their hard work, we would have had much bigger fires causing much bigger damage," Hardman said. "On behalf of all Victorians I would like to thank them because what they did on Boxing Day in extreme fire danger saved a lot more anguish and pain that Victorians now don't have to suffer."

Emergency services described the Boxing Day conditions as some of the worst they had seen since the Black Summer fires of 2019-20.

Three homes and 11 outbuildings have been lost in the Grampians fire so far.

urn:contentItem:6D3H-DR11-DY66-52V2-00000-00See the bushfire risk for Western Victoria this spring2024-10-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:24ZLexisNexisSee the bushfire risk for Western Victoria this spring

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Madeleine Stuchbery

Western Victoria is bracing for increased bushfire risk this spring, as national agencies prepare resources for the coming months.

It comes as the State Government's own analysis of residual fire fuel loads in the region sit seven per cent higher than targets, with Bureau of Meteorology climatic forecasts for spring highlighting a potential early start to bushfire season through the Wimmera, Grampians National Park, and the Mallee.

The National Emergency Management Agency has flagged areas of Australia, including Victoria's far west and southwest, as particularly vulnerable to fire risk this spring, following "an unusually dry autumn and winter".

Dry winter conditions aligns with the Victorian Government's own analysis of residual bushfire risk to the state, with the government's fuel-driven bushfire risk for the Grampians region and district in 2022-23 sitting at 77 per cent, seven per cent higher than the target of 70 per cent for the region.

Forest Fire Management chief officer Chris Hardman said the FFMVic has reduced bushfire risk across more than 138,000ha of public lands - including the Grampians region - throughout the year, "building on the 90,000ha treated last year".

It is understood FFMVic has undertaken planned burning this year, including ecological burns at Wilsons Promontory, and mosaic burns in the Otways and Lower Glenelg National Park.

"This isn't just about a single burn or one season, it's about ongoing work we've done in the past and continue to do year round, as well as our future plans to keep protecting our communities," Mr Hardman said.

"In addition to managing bushfire risk on public land, FFMVic is ready to respond with more than 3000 personnel working alongside our emergency sector partners to keep communities safe and informed about bushfire risk and how best prepare over the summer season."

urn:contentItem:6F5J-F4W3-S2T5-H2D7-00000-00Bushfire risk and native forest logging: David Lindenmayer responds to South East Timber Association2025-02-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:24ZLexisNexisBushfire risk and native forest logging: David Lindenmayer responds to South East Timber AssociationContributor,ARR.News

Professor David Lindenmayer AO, 19 February 2025. This submission is in response to the article An alternative perspective to David Lindenmayer: South East Timber Association, published on ARR.News on 14 February 2025. The entire series of articles and interchanges is listed below.

In response to the South East Timber Association’s (SETA) critique, I want to clarify the scientific evidence and address the inaccuracies in their claims.

Logging increases fire risk – the consequences of ignoring the evidence

SETA disputes the well-documented link between logging and increased fire severity, but the scientific consensus is clear: logging fundamentally alters forests in ways that make them more flammable. The science is clear that logged forests almost always burn at higher severity than intact forest – as seen in the Black Summer wildfires from north-eastern Victoria to north-eastern New South Wales (Lindenmayer et al. 2022b) – an effect that lasts from 40-70 years after a forest has been logged (Taylor et al. 2014) (Wilson et al. 2022).

What’s at stake here isn’t just an academic debate—it’s the safety of rural communities. Fire authorities, including the NSW Rural Fire Service, already recognise this risk. During the catastrophic 2019–2020 wildfires, operational maps flagged recently logged areas as high-risk zones due to excessive debris accumulation. This isn’t just theory; it’s an acknowledged hazard in real-world firefighting.

The reasons for the link between logging and increased fire risk are well understood: logged forests are drier, windier, and littered with hundreds of tonnes of debris, creating ideal conditions for intense and severe wildfires (Lindenmayer and Zylstra 2024). This has been documented not just in Australia, but globally—including both North America and South America (Lindenmayer and Zylstra 2024).

Dismissing scientific findings from detailed empirical studies that show the link between logging and wildfire isn’t just misleading—it’s dangerous. If we ignore what the science and firefighting agencies are telling us, we increase the likelihood of more devastating fires, putting lives, property, and ecosystems at risk. Rather than debating well-established facts, the focus should be on solutions: that is, both preventing future logging-driven fire risks and also investing in smarter fire management strategies that protect both people and the environment (Lindenmayer et al. 2022a).

Logging coupe and large burned stump, Hartz Mountain, Tasmania, June 2024.Photo: supplied

Native forest logging is not economically viable

The economic case for native forest logging is weak. Time and again, financial analyses have shown that native forest logging operates at a major loss when subsidies and environmental costs are accounted for (Frontier Economics and ANU 2021, Frontier Economics 2023). Public funds continue to prop up a native forest logging industry (Chapman et al. 2025) that degrades water supplies, biodiversity, and carbon stores—all of which economic accounting studies have shown have significantly higher long-term value than native forest logging (Keith et al. 2017). The future lies in plantation-based forestry (Lindenmayer and Taylor 2022), not in the continued destruction of native forests.

Logging is driving species declines

SETA downplays the impact of logging on biodiversity, but the reality is undeniable: native forest logging is a major driver of habitat destruction (Ward et al. 2024). Species like the critically endangered Leadbeater’s Possum are on the brink due to habitat loss. Old-growth forests cannot simply be "replaced" with young regrowth. The science is clear—logging fragments ecosystems, removes critical nesting sites, and pushes species towards extinction. It is also critical to understand that recent studies show that the recovery of biodiversity following wildfires is severely impaired when forests have been subject to repeated previous disturbances, including past logging (Lindenmayer et al. 2019). This was a key result from a recent major analysis of the effects on the 2019-2020 Black Summer wildfires on biodiversity (Driscoll et al. 2024).

The way forward: smarter fire management

Rather than continuing to debate well-established science, efforts should be directed toward solutions that reduce fire risk and protect both people and the environment. Victoria’s fire management authorities have already demonstrated in just the last week, the effectiveness of proactive suppression strategies. Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) has successfully used aerial water-bombing and rapid air attack responses to control recent fire ignitions, particularly those caused by lightning strikes. These targeted interventions prevent small fires from escalating into large-scale disasters, underscoring the importance of early detection and rapid response. The best time to fight fires is when they are small (Plucinski 2012). Using new technology to help us do that is critical (Lindenmayer et al. 2022a) – something that engineers and scientists at The Australian National University have been working intensively on for several years now (Lindenmayer et al. 2022a).

The next step in strengthening fire management is developing and implementing advanced drone technology. Emerging high-tech drone systems have the potential to revolutionise firefighting by providing real-time fire surveillance, detecting ignitions faster than ever before, and even carrying out autonomous suppression efforts in hazardous conditions (Yebra et al. 2021). For example, new generation drones can carry payloads of 1000kg and hit targets such as recent ignitions with extraordinary precision. Investing in these innovations—rather than continuing a logging regime that makes forests more fire-prone—is the logical path forward. Moreover, developing these technologies offers important business and export opportunities for Australia to help tackle the global problem of increasing fire risk in forests (Bousfield et al. 2023).

Conclusion

The scientific and economic evidence overwhelmingly supports ending native forest logging—not only to protect biodiversity and water supplies but also to reduce bushfire risk and limit economic losses from a failing and highly subsidized industry (Lindenmayer 2024). The ongoing degradation of native forests contradicts both environmental responsibility and public safety. With modern fire management strategies proving their effectiveness and technological advancements offering even greater possibilities, the focus must shift toward smarter, science-driven solutions. The future of Australia’s forests should be built on sound economics, resilience, conservation and innovative fire mitigation—not industry myths that put communities at risk.

References- Bousfield, C., D. B. Lindenmayer, and D. Edwards. 2023. Major and increasing wildfire-driven losses of timber stocks globally. Nature GeoScience 16:1145–1150.- Chapman, B., J. urn:contentItem:6DV7-31T3-SFBN-T2BJ-00000-00Bushfire slows after threatening campers at Cape Otway in Victoria's south-west2025-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:24ZLexisNexisBushfire slows after threatening campers at Cape Otway in Victoria's south-westBy Harrison Tippet and staff

Victorian firefighters bring a bushfire at Cape Otway under control, after some campers were evacuated in the early hours of Wednesday morning.

Campers remain at an evacuation centre in Victoria's south-west after an overnight bushfire threatened Cape Otway near the Great Ocean Road. 

More than 1,000 locals and campers were alerted by emergency text messages in the early hours of Wednesday morning and urged to leave the area after the blaze took hold at Blanket Bay Road.

It grew to roughly 15 hectares in size before firefighters managed to slow its spread.

But authorities have warned the situation could change at any time and have urged those in the busy tourist region to monitor updates.

Firefighting crews from surrounding areas worked to slow the spread of the fire. (Supplied: CFA Birregurra)

Some campers in the area were evacuated, while others were told to shelter in place. (Supplied: CFA Birregurra)

Authorities say the bushfire grew to roughly 15 hectares in size. (Supplied: CFA Birregurra)

Most campers evacuated in the dead of night, but Forest Fire Management Victoria Chief Fire Officer Chris Hardman said a group of campers was not able to safely leave.

"We've actually got about 100 campers at Blanket Bay campground that are isolated. It's just not safe to get them out at the moment," he told ABC Radio Melbourne.

Fire authorities were alerted to the blaze in the early hours of Wednesday morning. (Supplied: Apollo Bay Fire and Rescue)

Some campers were unable to evacuate because conditions were too dangerous. (Supplied: Conservation Ecology Centre)

The fire grew to roughly 15 hectares in size before firefighters managed to slow its spread. (Supplied: Conservation Ecology Centre)

Locals have been told it is not yet safe to return to Cape Otway. (Supplied: Conservation Ecology Centre)

He said the isolated campers were not in any danger and another 22 people had also been relocated to Cape Otway Lightstation.

"They're very safe there. They've got firefighting resources with them so there's no immediate danger," he said.

'Dazed' campers woken up for bushfire evacuation

Castlemaine resident Ricky Carson was camping at the Bimbi Park caravan park with his family when he woke to "noises and horns".

"Then you hear these words of 'fire, fire', some campers starting to walk out and move around," he told the ABC from an Apollo Bay evacuation centre.

Mr Carson said many campers were feeling "dazed and confused" as the campsite manager calmly told them there was a bushfire in the area and they should evacuate.

"When you're hearing it's a bushfire, just a couple of kilometres away, yeah, it starts to really kick in a bit," he said.

"It's something the family and friends here will remember for just a little while."

German tourist Norbit Sehmer had been joined by his mother for part of his holiday around Australia.

They were staying at Bimbi Park for just one night as they drove along the Great Ocean Road on their way to Adelaide.

"We couldn't know that it would turn out in such an adventure," Mr Sehmer said.

On Wednesday morning, he and his mother were waiting at the Apollo Bay relief centre to hear when they could return to the collect their car that was left behind during the evacuation.

He said someone had woken them at 2am and told them they had to leave.

"We basically just took our passports and some money and left," he said.

Regularly updated bushfire plan proved successful

The caravan park's owner Katrina Fotinas and her son Nathaniel praised the campers for their quick response to the emergency.

"All of our guests were calm and we had no problems and within an hour everyone was out of the park," Ms Fotinas said.

She said the family had run the caravan park for 20 years and re-wrote their bushfire plan annually, including assigning which family members would be responsible for evacuating different zones of the ground.

"We did it this morning and it worked," she said.

"And we hope it doesn't ever happen ever again."

Nathaniel Fotinas said there was only one hiccup.

"Someone lost their keys," he said.

"That wasn't good. That was a bit nervous."

Great Ocean Road Coast and Parks Authority emergency manager Sam Liston said authorities had worked hard to ensure guests staying at the Cape Otway Lightstation and nearby bushwalkers knew the safest thing was to shelter in place.

"There was a few delays in getting contact with people, but we were able to respond pretty swiftly to notify our guests and make sure they were going to be safe at the lightstation," he said.

Cause of fire yet to be determined

Investigations into what started the bushfire continue.

Port Campbell CFA Captain Katy Millard said there was no lightning around the Otways overnight.

She said the area was the driest she had ever seen.

"We have a very high fuel load," Captain Millard said.

"There's a lot of dry matter on the floor of the forest so it doesn't take very much for that to catch on fire."

She said it was fortunate that crews were able to access the fire quickly to get it under control.

"The biggest issue was that it was in the forest, so big tankers like this weren't as useful," she said.

"We had to take smaller vehicles so we could access the fire in more difficult terrain."

urn:contentItem:6DD8-6SJ1-JD34-V1HD-00000-00Prepare now: summer fire restrictions to begin in less than two weeks2024-11-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:24ZLexisNexisPrepare now: summer fire restrictions to begin in less than two weeksMonique Patterson

The Fire Danger Period for Warrnambool will begin later this month.

The period will officially begin on Monday, November 25, 2024, and end on Thursday, May 1, 2025.

Restrictions will also come into force on the same date for Corangamite, Moyne, Glenelg and Southern Grampians shires.

The restrictions mean no open fires can be lit in any municipality without a permit.

In October, the Australasian Fire And Emergency Services Authorities Council (AFAC) forecast an above average fire season for the region.

Forest Fire Management Victoria far south-west district manager Sheree Mirtschin urged residents to be prepared.

"The forecast for an above-average fire season for the far south-west highlights the importance of taking a year-round approach to preparing for summer bushfires," Ms Mirtschin said.

Planned burns conducted throughout the year "Throughout the year, we've conducted planned burns across the district when conditions permit, while also completing maintenance on strategic fire breaks and access tracks; as well as mulching, mowing, slashing and spraying as part of our preparations.

"Now is also the time for the community to make sure they are ready for summer by preparing their properties and having up-to-date fire plans in place."

The warning comes after the Australian and New Zealand National Council for fire and emergency services (AFAC) on September 4 showed most of the western part of the state was at high risk.

Western and south-west areas endured a dry autumn and winter, drying out soil, grass and forests and draining dams and rivers.

CFA chief officer Jason Heffernan said it added up to a much earlier start to the fire season than normal.

"We're asking all Victorians in high-risk areas to take simple actions to prepare their family and property as the weather begins to warm," Mr Heffernan said.

Record dry autumn The high-risk forecast from AFAC looks at two key indicators: conditions since the start of the year, and the outlook for the next few months.

CFA District 5 acting assistant chief fire officer David Ferguson said south-west Victoria had been unseasonably dry in 2024.

"What we had was really low rainfall in February, March, April, May and June," Mr Ferguson said.

"It was especially low in areas like Coleraine and Casterton, record dryness for those localities."

District 5 covers everywhere from Warrnambool, north past Hamilton to Balmoral.

Fire Danger Period restrictions A written permit is required to burn off grass, undergrowth, weeds or other vegetation during the FDP. You can apply for a permit at firepermits.vic.gov.au. It can also be issued by the Municipal Fire Prevention Officer or the CFA District Office. Lighting fires in the open without a permit can bring a penalty of more than $21,800 and/or 12 months imprisonment. Residents and visitors to the region can Download the VicEmergency app and keep an eye on the CFA website for further information about the Fire Danger Period and Total Fire Ban days.

urn:contentItem:6DP4-F6N3-RX92-X3RN-00000-00Fire threat to regional Victoria2024-11-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:24ZLexisNexisNEWS3Fire threat to regional VictoriaBen Silvester

CFA research reveals how fire danger has changed since 1970.

Bushfire danger has increased in Victoria across every single measure since 2001, outstripping the rest of Australia, according to Country Fire Authority analysis.

The research has revealed Victoria now faces far more fire danger days, longer fire seasons, and more widespread and damaging bushfires than it did from 1970 to 2000.

Despite several mild years following the 2019-20 Black Summer fires, the CFA analysis also showed bushfire danger rising steadily over the coming decade and tripling in some parts of the state by 2100.

A hotter and drier Victoria

CFA fire risk research and development manager Sarah Harris said the changes in Victoria since 2001 were clear and dramatic.

"We've reconstructed Victoria's fire weather over the past 50 years and that data has shown a significant increase in extreme fire weather," Dr Harris said.

There are only six years on record where Victoria has had more than 100 days of very high fire danger - a Forest Fire Danger index of above 25. They all happened since 2002.

But the average number of high danger days has also increased.

Between 1972 and 2000 there were 66 days per year where at least 10 per cent of the state had very high fire danger.

From 2001 to 2016 that jumped to 94 days, effectively an extra month of dangerous fire weather each year.

Accordingly, Victoria's fire season is lasting much longer than it used to.

More bushfires, more area burned

Dr Harris said it wasn't just the fire danger that had increased, so had actual fires.

"We've seen an increase in the number of fires, but more importantly in the area burned by fires each year," Dr Harris said.

While the million hectare mark had been breached three times in the past 20 years, it had only happened once in the prior 80 years.

The pattern continued at lower thresholds, with years where 400,000 hectares were burned becoming more than five times likelier since 2003.

It's going to keep getting worse

Since the Black Summer fires in 2019-20 there have been several La Nina years with milder weather.

Dr Harris said climate systems like ENSO - which drive the El Nino/La Nina cycle - will bring variability from year to year, the overall trend is for more frequent and intense fires.

"In the north-west and central areas of Victoria we are looking at a doubling of the very high fire danger days by the end of the century," Dr Harris said.

In some areas that could mean half the year is spend in very high fire danger.

What's in store this summer?

The CFA is currently deep into its calculations for the 2024-25 summer fire outlook.

"We've had some significant rainfall deficits in the south-west region for at least 18 months," Dr Harris said.

"But after a dry winter and spring, we're not just talking about the southwest now.

"Parts of the north-east of Victoria are starting to dry out. And that south-west Gippsland area heading across to Mornington Peninsula are also dry as well.

"So with a warm summer coming, that's really concerning."

urn:contentItem:6DP4-F6N3-RX92-X3S4-00000-00Artificial Intelligence deployed in central Victoria to stop bushfires2024-11-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:24ZLexisNexisArtificial Intelligence deployed in central Victoria to stop bushfiresDavid Chapman

Funding has also been handed out to emergency crews for vehicles.

Central Victoria is being braced for a particularly bad bushfire season with new vehicles and even Artificial Intelligence (AI) being deployed to prevent disaster.

Smoke-detecting AI software using 24/7 ground cameras have been mounted on specific fire lookouts across the state, including Mt Ida near Heathcote for the 2024-2025 fire season

It's all part of a $1.5 million joint venture between the federal and state governments.

'AI is OK'

Federal Minister for Emergency Management Senator Jenny McAllister said the early bushfire technology deployed in this trial could help authorities detect and suppress bushfires before they impact communities .

"New technology such as artificial intelligence has the potential to transform how we prepare and respond to disasters," she said.

It was a line echoed by Victorian Minister for Environment Steve Dimopoulos.

"This AI trial gives us the opportunity to explore how advancements in science and technology can be utilised to stay ahead of the threat of bushfires - ensuring we're prepared with the best tools available to detect risk faster while keeping our communities and environment safer," he said.

The trial is being undertaken by Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic). It is hoped the AI software will help when lookouts aren't staffed after hours or due to health and safety concerns, such as extreme weather conditions.

NextGen truck for SES unit

Meanwhile, Wedderburn's VICSES unit - which was on the verge of folding this year - is set to receive a new heavy rescue truck courtesy of the state government.

The NextGen Heavy Rescue Truck is worth $405,000 and will feature better ergonomics, LED and cabin door lighting and wind speed detection capability.

It will also feature dedicated storage for food and hydration for extended operations, a chainsaw work bench, and improved locker stowage for easy access to equipment.

A VICSES fleet working group designed the truck to make sure it's custom built to serve the local volunteers' needs.

This investment comes after Wedderburn residents experienced heavy rainfall over the Christmas and New Year period last year which led to trees down, blocked roads and a serious incident in the Nardoo Creek behind the unit .

The unit was at risk of folding earlier this year due to a lack of members.

Now, the reinvigorated VICSES Wedderburn Unit is currently home to 14 volunteers and received 98 requests for assistance last financial year.

Production of the new truck for Wedderburn will begin next year.

Mobile command centre

And in more news ahead of a forecast ominous bushfire season, Malmsbury CFA will be getting a Field Command Vehicle - XLT valued at $71,000.

Victorian Minister for Emergency Services Jaclyn Symes announced the brigade's boon as part of the 2024-25 Volunteer Emergency Services Equipment Program (VESEP) grants which sees recipients share in more than $15 million to purchase new equipment, improve emergency response capability and support community safety.

CFA and FFMVic crews battled a grass fire in Bendigo earlier this month, which could serve as a warning of bigger blazes to come. Picture by Darren Howe

urn:contentItem:6DKC-H4F1-JD34-V003-00000-00Summer's not a 'silly season'2024-12-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:24ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 21Summer's not a 'silly season'Chris Hardman

Last week you might have noticed a pick-up in news articles and broadcasts forecasting a hot, dry summer, and high potential for fire in some areas of the state.

That news has come from the seasonal summer outlook, distributed by the Australasian Fire and Emergency Services Authorities Council (AFAC). The Seasonal Bushfire Outlook for Summer gives a picture of the likelihood of fire over the summer months, at both a state and national level.

This year's outlook for Victoria predicts higher potential for fire for most of western Victoria, as well as south-west Gippsland, including Mornington Peninsula, greater Melbourne and north-east Victoria.

The potential has been assessed this way because of the dry conditions in those areas, the availability of vegetation (e.g. grass, leaves, bark, shrubs and fallen branches) to 'fuel' fires, high temperatures and the continuing lack of rainfall to bring moisture to the landscape. The fire potential elsewhere in Victoria has been assessed as 'normal', but hot, dry and windy weather can still pose a risk in areas dominated by forests, woodlands, or dense, low shrubs.

'Normal' is no reason to be complacent, but you should know Victoria is prepared and our land and fire agencies have worked all year to reduce our bushfire risk.

On public land this year, FFMVic carried out risk reduction works across more than 138,000 hectares - and because it isn't just about this summer or this season, I'm happy to tell you we also carried out works on more than 90,000 hectares the year before. The impacts are cumulative.

Risk reduction works include planned burns, mowing, mulching, slashing and spraying. Collectively, we call these works 'fuel management'. They reduce the amount of vegetation (e.g. grass, leaves, bark, shrubs and fallen branches) available to 'fuel' a fire, thereby reducing the likely speed or intensity of a bushfire. These qualities can help fire crews to respond and put out fires while they are still small. Visit plannedburns.ffm.vic.gov.au

Last month we saw some of the reward for those efforts, with a fire in the Great Otway National Park - the Chapple Vale-Colac Tree Road fire - showing reduced spread in the footprint of one of our planned burns back in August.

Recent weeks have also shown how we work together with, and alongside, our emergency sector partners. On the frontline, FFMVic has close to 1800 personnel, including full-time and seasonal firefighters, fire lookout observers and fire support officers. In recent months, many of them have completed training and accreditation to make sure they are equipped with the skills and knowledge they need to be safe and help keep communities safe this summer.

They are supported by hundreds of emergency and incident management staff, including surge staff who have a fire and emergency role, in addition to their day job, as well as firefighting equipment. This includes tankers, earthmoving equipment and aircraft positioned across the state - as well as additional aircraft that can be called upon when needed. Summer is a festive time in Victoria. But opportunity is never without responsibility. Now is also the time to prepare yourself and your loved ones for the fire season. Here are some quick tips to help you get started.

Five tips for Victorians 1. Visit cfa.vic.gov.au to help you get started on a Bushfire Plan so you know what you will do in case of fire

2. Download and get to know the VicEmergency app - then set up 'watch zones' and turn on notifications

3. Get to know the Australian Fire Danger Ratings System - and work out what fire danger rating will trigger your Bushfire Plan

4. Plan your travel - visit exploreoutdoors.vic.gov.au to help you stay safe when visiting state forests

5. Never leave a campfire unattended - if they are cool to touch, they are safe to leave.

Wishing everyone a safe and happy festive season.

- Chris Hardman, Chief Fire Officer, Forest Fire Management Victoria

urn:contentItem:6DPK-2WT3-RRWT-B1JD-00000-00More than 300 firefighters work to contain Grampians National Park bushfire2024-12-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:24ZLexisNexisMore than 300 firefighters work to contain Grampians National Park bushfireBen Fraser

Update 8.20pm: Authorities have provided an update on the bushfire as they work to contain it overnight.

The Grampians National Park bushfire is now 29,000 hectares in size with a fire perimeter of 192km.

More than 300 firefighters from Forest Fire Management Victoria, CFA and Fire Rescue Victoria are on the ground and at least another 100 remain in the Incident Control Centre in Horsham.

The warning for Pomonal and Lake Fyans residents to leave is now downgraded, but it is strongly recommended that those remaining in the area be prepared to leave.

Residents should monitor the situation as an increase in wind speed, a change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can mean the situation is worsening.

Communities near Wartook are advised to be vigilant conditions move the firefront along the eastern wall.

Almost 31,000ha has been burnt since December 17.

Update 4pm: State Control Centre spokesperson Luke Hegarty reiterated the advice for people in the Bellfield, Fyans Creek and Halls Gap areas.

"The advice there is to evacuate immediately," he said.

"There are relief centres established at Ararat and Stawell.

"There are also other emergency warnings associated with the Grampians fire with advice to leave immediately for Lake Fyans, Pomonal, Watgania and Mafeking."

Mr Hegarty said all of these warnings are on the VicEmergency app and the VicEmergency website.

"If you're travelling over the next few days, it's really important that before you start your travel, to check the Vic emergency app, the Vic emergency website, or call the Vic emergency hotline on 1800226226, and listen to emergency broadcasters such as ABC local Radio."

Update 4pm: State Control Centre spokesperson Luke Hegarty reiterated the advice for people in the Bellfield, Fyans Creek and Halls Gap areas.

"The advice there is to evacuate immediately," he said.

"There are relief centres established at Ararat and Stawell.

"There are also other emergency warnings associated with the Grampians fire with advice to leave immediately for Lake Fyans, Pomonal, Watgania and Mafeking."

Mr Hegarty said all of these warnings are on the VicEmergency app and the VicEmergency website.

"If you're travelling over the next few days, it's really important that before you start your travel, to check the Vic emergency app, the Vic emergency website, or call the Vic emergency hotline on 1800226226, and listen to emergency broadcasters such as ABC local Radio."

Update 3pm: If you are located in Bellfield, Bellfield Settlement, Flat Rock Crossing, Fyans Creek, Grampians Junction or Halls Gap, it is recommended you evacuate immediately and move to a safer location away from the fire.

Recordings of Community meetings are available from https://www.facebook.com/VicEmergencyGrampians.

Update 12pm: Residents of Halls Gap, Bellfield, Bellfield Settlement, Flat Rock Crossing and Fyans Creek have been told to leave immediately.

The bushfire has reached Lake Bellfield and the Major Mitchell Plateau, and is moving in a northerly direction towards Halls Gap.

Crews and aircraft continue to work in the area; backburning operations will be conducted today and smoke will be visible.

A second relief centre has opened as more people leave the bushfire-affected Grampians National Park.

Grampians Community Health opened its doors at 22 Patrick Street Stawell.

Alexandra Oval Community Centre relief centre remains open at 1 Waratah Avenue.

Emergency services issued a warning to residents of Barton, Jallukur and Londonderry.

Earlier: The Grampians National Park bushfire is edging closer to Halls Gap and Pomonal as the bushfire triples in size.

Holidaymakers were urged to leave the Grampians as firefighters battled the 28,100 ha blaze on multiple fronts.

The main front travelled north towards Halls Gap as southerly winds pushed the bushfire closer to the popular holiday destination.

Parks Victoria closed the Grampians National Park and urged travellers to use the Alexandra Oval Community Centre relief centre at 1 Waratah Avenue.

During the community meeting in Ararat, Emergency Management Victoria controller Mark Gunning said Pomonal was not under direct threat.

"We have strike teams ... who are extremely effective in suppressing fires," he said.

Overnight the fire crossed Redman Road and travelled in two directions as it burned around Lake Belfield.

Another front is travelling northerly direction towards Mt William.

Backburning operations will be conducted today, and smoke will be visible.

Residents of Moyston, Barton, Jallukur and Willaura are being warned to stay on high alert as another front slowly moves east.

Community meetings planned for Pomonal and Halls Gap have been relocated.

The first meeting at the Ararat Town Hall at 10am provided an update on the Grampians bushfire. It was live-streamed on the Ararat Rural City Council Facebook page.

An additional community meeting was held in Stawell Town Hall at 11.30am and was Northern Grampians Shire Council Facebook page.

Check the VicTraffic website for road closures.

The blaze comes just 10 months after the catastrophic Pomonal bushfire that destroyed 44 homes on February 13.

urn:contentItem:6DNF-MMJ1-JBJ7-N16G-00000-00Tax hit for homeowners, EV drivers as Vic deficit blows out to $3.6b2024-12-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:24ZLexisNexisTax hit for homeowners, EV drivers as Vic deficit blows out to $3.6bGus McCubbing

Victorian Treasurer Tim Pallas revealed property owners face a doubled fire services levy while electric vehicle drivers will lose a registration discount.

A fire services levy on Victorian homeowners will be doubled and an electric vehicle tax rebate axed as the Allan Labor government moves to plug holes in a budget with a deficit that has blown out to $3.6 billion this year.

Link to Image

Justin McManus

Treasurer Tim Pallas announced the extra revenue measures on Friday as he released the government's mid-year budget review, which also reported a small improvement in the state's net debt position.

The Treasury update says net debt will rise to $187 billion by 2028 from $155.2 billion next year, $500 million less that figures in the May budget. The budget deficit had increased by $1.4 billion since the $2.2 billion forecast in the May budget, the papers reveal.

Mr Pallas announced that the rate of the state's fire services levy - collected by councils for the state government to pay for the emergency service - would be doubled, increasing revenue from the tax by $2.14 billion over the next four years.

The median cost per household will rise from $191 to $254, but commercial properties will pay an extra $492, while the bill for farmers will jump from $621 to $1299, under the changes.

The levy will be renamed the emergency services and volunteers fund and retooled to provide money towards other emergency services, such as Triple Zero Victoria and Forest Fire Management Victoria.

"The state always cuts it cloth to meet the needs of the community. We have to accept we are living in a changing and more dangerous environment, and we have to make provisions for it," Mr Pallas said.

The government will also axe a $100 discount on registrations for EVs from January 2026, which is forecast to add $165 million to state revenue by 2028.

And Victoria's congestion levy, a parking tax in inner-city Melbourne, will be expanded and increased, bringing in an extra $300 million over four years.

Mr Pallas said he did not expect the cancellation of the EV rebate to discourage EV takeup - it's original purpose was to encourage it - and that the government did not "need to be out there proselytising that people should get onto EVs".

"It's a little rich to continue a process of subsiding the registration of these vehicles in circumstances where you're not paying for the use of the road," he said.

Net debt to GSP is projected to climb from 24.2 per cent to 25 per cent in 2025 before peaking at 25.2 per cent in 2026 and dropping back to 25 per cent in 2027-28.

Pressure has been growing on Premier Jacinta Allan over Labor's management of the state economy, and escalated when independent economist Saul Eslake published a detailed critique in The Australian Financial Review last month.

Ms Allan has rejected the criticism, and this week announced a plan to try to revive business investment in the state.

On Friday, Mr Eslake said the dire state of Victoria's finances appeared "little changed" in the latest update, adding: "At least it hasn't got any worse."

But the government's revenue measures fell far short of what was needed to start reining in ballooning state debt and government spending.

"There's been no material change in the government's fiscal strategy - no serious effort to rein in either operating or infrastructure spending," Mr Eslake said.

"[There's] a little bit of additional revenue-raising, and as yet no credible path back to an overall cash surplus which would allow it to start paying down debt, as opposed to merely running it up at a slower pace."

Meanwhile, high-profile Liberal MP Sam Groth quit the opposition frontbench on Friday in what could be the first sign of a leadership move against embattled Liberal chief John Pesutto.

On Thursday, Mr Pesutto was found to have defamed ousted Liberal MP Moira Deeming as a Nazi sympathiser and ordered to pay her $300,000, worsening an internal crisis in the party.

Mr Groth - a former professional tennis player who has made no secret of his ambition to be premier - said as "a matter of conscience" he could not stay on the frontbench following Mr Pesutto's refusal to step down following the verdict.

Upper house MP Bev McArthur on Friday urged Mr Pesutto to test his leadership by calling a party meeting.

Victorian Treasurer Tim Pallas this week said his state was the nation's strongest performing econony.

urn:contentItem:6DP4-F6H3-RS64-M3C2-00000-00Prepare now: summer fire restrictions to begin in less than two weeks2024-11-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:24ZLexisNexisPrepare now: summer fire restrictions to begin in less than two weeksMonique Patterson

District municipalities will also enter the Fire Danger Period.

The Fire Danger Period for Warrnambool will begin later this month.

The period will officially begin on Monday, November 25, 2024, and end on Thursday, May 1, 2025.

Restrictions will also come into force on the same date for Corangamite, Moyne, Glenelg and Southern Grampians shires.

The restrictions mean no open fires can be lit in any municipality without a permit.

In October, the Australasian Fire And Emergency Services Authorities Council (AFAC) forecast an above average fire season for the region.

Forest Fire Management Victoria far south-west district manager Sheree Mirtschin urged residents to be prepared.

"The forecast for an above-average fire season for the far south-west highlights the importance of taking a year-round approach to preparing for summer bushfires," Ms Mirtschin said.

Planned burns conducted throughout the year

"Throughout the year, we've conducted planned burns across the district when conditions permit, while also completing maintenance on strategic fire breaks and access tracks; as well as mulching, mowing, slashing and spraying as part of our preparations.

"Now is also the time for the community to make sure they are ready for summer by preparing their properties and having up-to-date fire plans in place."

The warning comes after the Australian and New Zealand National Council for fire and emergency services (AFAC) on September 4 showed most of the western part of the state was at high risk.

Western and south-west areas endured a dry autumn and winter, drying out soil, grass and forests and draining dams and rivers.

CFA chief officer Jason Heffernan said it added up to a much earlier start to the fire season than normal.

"We're asking all Victorians in high-risk areas to take simple actions to prepare their family and property as the weather begins to warm," Mr Heffernan said.

Record dry autumn

The high-risk forecast from AFAC looks at two key indicators: conditions since the start of the year, and the outlook for the next few months.

CFA District 5 acting assistant chief fire officer David Ferguson said south-west Victoria had been unseasonably dry in 2024.

"What we had was really low rainfall in February, March, April, May and June," Mr Ferguson said.

"It was especially low in areas like Coleraine and Casterton, record dryness for those localities."

District 5 covers everywhere from Warrnambool, north past Hamilton to Balmoral.

Fire Danger Period restrictions

A written permit is required to burn off grass, undergrowth, weeds or other vegetation during the FDP. You can apply for a permit at firepermits.vic.gov.au. It can also be issued by the Municipal Fire Prevention Officer or the CFA District Office.

Lighting fires in the open without a permit can bring a penalty of more than $21,800 and/or 12 months imprisonment.

Residents and visitors to the region can Do wnload the VicEmergency app and keep an eye on the CFA website for further information about the Fire Danger Period and Total Fire Ban days.

A firetruck near a fire near Mount Buangor in early 2024. File picture by Lachlan Bence

urn:contentItem:6DNR-6C83-RSHB-712W-00000-00Firefighters continue to battle Grampians National Park blaze near Dunkeld2024-12-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:24ZLexisNexisFirefighters continue to battle Grampians National Park blaze near DunkeldLucas Holmes, Ben Fraser

Update 9.25pm: Since a bushfire took hold, more than 520ha have burned in the Grampians National Park.

About a dozen firefighting crews and helicopters are battling the blaze about 20km north of Dunkeld.

Fortunately, the bushfire has not impacted private property.

Forest Fire Management Victoria has issued the following advice:

Road Closures:

Grampians Tourist Road is closed from Jimmy Creek Road to the intersection of Victoria Valley Road. Yarram Gap Road is closed from Grampians Tourist Road to Moyston-Dunkeld Road. Speed restrictions are in place along Grampians Tourist Road, south of Jimmy Creek. Grampians National Park visitor information and closures:

The southern part of the Grampians National Park, including the Grampians Peaks trail is closed from Jimmy Creek to Dunkeld. The areas north of Jimmy Creek remain open. Wannon Crossing campground is closed. All walking tracks and campgrounds in the southern area are closed The next update is expected at 10.30pm or as conditions change; however, this is the last update from us tonight.

To stay informed:

www.emergency.vic.gov.au VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 VicEmergency app Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. Update 6.50pm: The main bushfire north of Dunkeld has crossed Yarram Gap Road and continues to move in a north-easterly direction towards Mafeking.

Spot fires and embers are starting fires ahead of the main fire.

Emergency Services are warning residents in nearby affected communities to consider leaving now before conditions change.

Crews from Marnoo, Dadswells Bridge, Glenorchy & Riachella and District 16 have joined the strikeforce team in Willaura.

The next update is expected at 10pm or as conditions change.

Update 6.20pm: Residents northeast of the Yarram Gap Road have been told to stay alert and prepare to leave if the bushfire continues to spread.

People in Barton, Bellfield, Grampians, Jimmy Creek, Kia Ora, Mafeking, Mirranatwa, Moyston, Pomonal, Stavely, Watgania, Willaura and Willaura North were issued with the alert at 5pm.

Emergency services have said while there is currently no threat, you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes.

A strikeforce made up of crew members from Pomonal, Ararat, Great Western and Moyston will assist the nine crews fighting a blaze on Lynchs Crossing Road in Mafeking and seven crews working near Dunkeld.

Almost 280 hectares have been burnt since 2pm.

Yarram Gap Road is closed from Grampians Tourist Road to Moyston-Dunkeld Road.

Smoke is visible from nearby communities and roads.

More to come.

Earlier 4pm: Emergency services are responding to a bushfire in Grampians National Park on Tuesday, December 17.

A Watch and Act message has been issued for Grampians National Park near Yarram Gap Road at about 3.14pm.

This Advice message is being issued for Grampians, Jimmy Creek, Mafeking, Moyston, and Watgania.

Authorities say the bushfire is travelling from Lynchs Track in a north-easterly direction towards Yarram Gap Road.

Seven vehicles are responding to the bushfire which is not yet under control.

Yarram Gap Road is closed from Grampians Tourist Road to Moyston-Dunkeld Road.

The next update is expected by 7.20pm or as the situation changes.

Members of the public can report incidents of sick, injured, or orphaned native animals anywhere in the state to Wildlife Victoria's 24/7 wildlife emergency response service at (03) 8400 7300.

If your property has been impacted by fire or storms and you have urgent animal welfare needs, please contact the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.

An animal health team will assess livestock and provide advice to support your property's recovery.

What you should do:

Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. Protect yourself and your family. If you are away from home, do not return. If the situation changes or you feel unsafe you should leave:

Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area or a safer location. Impacts in your area:

Bushfires can spread quickly and are extremely dangerous. Trees can be extremely hazardous during a bushfire or high winds. Avoid standing, parking or travelling in areas of fire affected trees. Bushfires can start spot fires and embers can travel large distances ahead of the main fire. Grampians National Park visitor information and closures:

Grampians Peaks Trail is closed from Jimmy Creek Road Trail Head to Dunkeld. Wannon Crossing campground is closed. All walking tracks and campgrounds in the southern area are closed. VicEmergency advised community members to check multiple sources to stay informed:

www.emergency.vic.gov.au VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 VicEmergency app Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires) Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Bushfires can spread quickly and are extremely dangerous. Trees can be extremely hazardous during a bushfire or high winds. Avoid standing, parking or travelling in areas of fire affected trees. Bushfires can start spot fires and embers can travel large distances ahead of the main fire. Grampians National Park visitor information and closures:

Grampians Peaks Trail is closed from Jimmy Creek Road Trail Head to Dunkeld. Wannon Crossing campground is closed. All walking tracks and campgrounds in the southern area are closed. VicEmergency advised community members to check multiple sources to stay informed:

www.emergency.vic.gov.au VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 VicEmergency app Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires) Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

urn:contentItem:6DR7-GDM3-S798-21RJ-00000-00Firefighters gearing up to battle blazes on Christmas Day ahead of fire danger spike2024-12-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:24ZLexisNexisFirefighters gearing up to battle blazes on Christmas Day ahead of fire danger spike

Warnings are in effect for Boxing Day fire conditions that could be the worst Victorians have experienced since Black Summer.

While many Australians will be sitting down to enjoy a Christmas lunch with loved ones on Wednesday, hundreds of firefighters are gearing up to battle bushfires on what could be the worst fire danger rating for Victoria in five years.

A total fire ban has been declared for all of Victoria on Thursday, with authorities warning conditions could be the worst the state has experienced since the Black Summer bushfires five years ago.

On Boxing Day, temperatures are forecast to hit the mid-40s in parts of the state, with troublesome hot, northerly winds predicted to blow ahead of a gusty westerly change.

There will be an extreme fire danger risk for all parts of Victoria, except for East Gippsland where a high fire danger is forecast.

The forecast was trouble for crews battling to contain a bushfire that had burnt through more than 40,000 hectares in the Grampians and continued to threaten nearby communities, including Moyston and Pomonal, which were ordered to evacuate immediately about 3pm on Christmas Day.

Alongside blazes in central Victoria at Bullengarook and at The Gurdies in the east of the state, authorities were also on high alert for new blazes that might spark elsewhere in the state.

Firefighters sacrifice family time for fire preparation

CFA volunteer Leigh Dwyer is one of the many firefighters sacrificing their holidays in order to help the community.

For Ms Dwyer, things will be particularly tough, with her property directly in the firing line.

"I focus on people, so I'm not really thinking about Christmas," she said.

"[Christmas will be] non-existent to be truthful. I've got a farm down the road, I'm actually preparing to be burnt out."

Ms Dwyer said Christmas will be spent packing possessions and moving them into town.

"I've got plenty of anxiety but I've been in it long enough to know that this is just going to happen," she said.

"If I'm not around at the farm there's no chance of me saving it, so just go out and do what you do for the community."

She said the response to the fires from the community had been "epic", with everyone doing their part to prepare.

Firefighters flood base camp

A base camp for fire crews has been set up in Ballarat's Victoria Park in anticipation of the spike.

From tomorrow, about 250 firefighters from CFA and Forest Fire Management will be stationed at the camp, which has showers, kitchen and accommodation facilities.

Among these firefighters will be some of the 100 interstate staff who have travelled to assist.

Ballarat City Fire Brigade captain Nicole McGrath would usually spend Christmas Eve wrapping presents, but yesterday she was on site helping get the base camp up and running ahead of the high-risk days.

"We are prepared as best we can be, but we are conscious that the conditions will be very challenging," she said.

CFA acting assistance chief fire officer Wayne Rigg got the call to set up the base camp on Sunday night.

Within two days, the operation was well underway and volunteers from a number of organisations, including the CFA, SES, and Rotary had stepped in to help by pitching tents and getting supplies in order.

"When things are going on in the community, the community responds," he said.

Residents near fires 'living on edge'

John David Beecham lives in Bullengarook where a fire has burned out of control during the week.

A longtime resident on the area, Mr Beecham knows all too well how quickly fire can spread.

"Fast. Too fast sometimes. We were here in '83 actually, Ash Wednesday, we lost the house," he said.

"So we're pretty well aware of what it's like. I was in CFA, but those days have passed."

While his son will remain to protect the property, Mr Beecham said he and his wife, both in their 90s, were leaving to stay with relatives.

He said he was expecting the worst from the extreme conditions forecast on Boxing Day.

"I'm not [feeling] very hopeful, I'll be glad when that day is over … and our son will be safe," he said.

Northern Grampians Shire deputy mayor and tourism business operator Justine Hide is among the Halls Gap residents spending Christmas away from home after evacuating from the town on Friday.

"We will make [Christmas Day] just as special as we would have at home," she said.

She said the bushfires are expected to have a huge impact on tourism operators.

"This is going to go on for months and months. It is the peak time when operators do use this as the opportunity to survive the quieter times in Halls Gap," Ms Hide said.

In Victoria Valley near Mirranatwa, Wildwood Wildlife Shelter operator Pam Turner said it would be challenging to transport rescued wildlife if they were told to evacuate.

"It's not like how you can grab your dog and cat, and pop them in the car."

She had done the best she could to prepare the property, including installing sprinklers, but it was unclear what the next few days would hold.

"We are living on edge. If that fire comes over the mountain it could be a fireball."

urn:contentItem:6DBC-0921-DY47-53VB-00000-00Dry thunderstorms could start hundreds of fires in Victoria, Bureau of Meteorology warns2024-11-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:24ZLexisNexisDry thunderstorms could start hundreds of fires in Victoria, Bureau of Meteorology warnsBy Gillian Aeria, Ashlee Aldridge and Laura Mayers

Victorian authorities brace for difficult fire conditions with high temperatures and storms with dry lightning forecast this week.

Warm temperatures and dry conditions have increased the fire risk across Victoria's north this week, the Bureau of Meterology warns.

Senior forecaster Michael Efron says warm to hot conditions are expected on Wednesday before a cold front moves through.

He says people need to be aware of the changing conditions.

"[It's] not ideal to see potential fires start across the state from thunderstorm activity, when we had a dry week."

On Wednesday, an extreme fire danger rating is forecast for the Mallee district, with the Wimmera and parts of Central Victoria rated as high.

Mr Efron said temperatures would be in the mid to high 30s with thunderstorms.

With minimal rain predicted there was potential for lightning to trigger hundreds of fires, he said.

Lightning strikes cause national park blaze

Lightning is believed to have started five fires in the state's north-east on Sunday afternoon including a bushfire in the Chiltern-Mount Pilot National Park about 20 kilometres east of Wangaratta.

CFA District 23 Commander Daryl Owen said more than a dozen appliances, including two aircraft, were called to Beechworth-Wangaratta Road at Everton Upper to battle the blaze in a joint effort by the CFA and Forest Fire Management.

He said while the 5-hectare fire was small, it was in "quite inaccessible terrain" and waterbombing was required to attack the blaze's perimeter.

Commander Owen said there was a small amount of rain in the state's north-east on Sunday morning.

"But from lunchtime, the humidity decreased, and the sun came through, and temperatures increased along with the wind," he said. 

"That saw some lightning strikes, which took hold in some trees and grassland within the bush."

Fire danger period starts for Loddon-Mallee

With an extreme fire danger forecast for the Mallee, CFA Assistant Chief Fire Officer for District 20 Mick Sporton urged residents to prepare over coming days with the environment "rapidly dying out".

"The grasslands are at about 80 per cent [dry] … and from midnight last night, the fire danger period came into effect," Mr Sporton said.

"The forest itself is extremely dry. With the forecasted weather this week, we'll be on high alert."

He said the focus over the past few days had been on preparing volunteers and strike teams in case they were needed, amid the hot and windy weather ahead.

"We always bang on about having a plan, but that's never more important [than] now," Mr Sporton said.

He advises people to have enough clothes and food packed, and a location where they could go should they need to leave quickly.

"Check in on your neighbours," Mr Sporton said.

"They may not be aware there's a high fire danger."

The fire danger period begins for the Buloke, Campaspe, Gannawarra, Loddon, Northern Grampians and Swan Hill local government areas on Monday.

urn:contentItem:6CRF-TDX1-JBN5-F14P-00000-00'Sacred ground' in ANZAC Cove under threat as fires rage across Türkiye, Anthony Albanese says2024-08-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:24ZLexisNexis'Sacred ground' in ANZAC Cove under threat as fires rage across Türkiye, Anthony Albanese says

Anthony Albanese warns of the possibility that fires raging in Türkiye might reach ANZAC graves in Gallipoli.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has warned of the possibility fires raging towards Gallipoli may reach the graves of Australian soldiers at ANZAC Cove.

"Our thoughts today are also with our friends in Türkiye. We understand there are efforts underway to control fires that are burning on the Gallipoli Peninsula," Mr Albanese said in a press conference on Friday.

"Gallipoli is, of course, sacred ground to both of our countries."

"Some 60,000 Australians served at Gallipoli during the eight-month campaign, and 8,700 Australians lost their lives," he said, referring to the Gallipoli campaign of World War I.

"18,000 were wounded during the campaign. And there were more than 7,200 Australians buried in cemeteries or listed as missing there."

"So our thoughts today are with those who continue to care for those cemeteries, and welcome thousands of Australians who visit ANZAC headstones each year, as they endure these difficult times."

Mr Albanese's statement comes after an update from the general manager for Türkiye's Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry, Bekir Karacabey, who said firefighters were managing the blaze.

"We are intervening non-stop from land and air with the guardians of #GreenHomeland to bring the forest fire in Eceabat, Çanakkale under control," Mr Karacabey wrote in a Facebook post, referencing the area where ANZAC Cove is located.

"Let's be careful to prevent other fires in these days when the risk of fire increases due to extraordinary weather conditions."

The Returned & Services League of Australia (RSL) said in a press release it didn't know whether fires in the area had damaged Australian war graves, but was monitoring the situation.

"The fires broke out earlier this week following high humidity and extreme temperatures in the region," the release read.

It noted that two months ago, Turkish authorities announced that record-breaking temperatures had resulted in a fivefold increase in forest fires compared to last year.

RSL Australia president Greg Melick said he understood that the site had been closed to protect the community and to facilitate fighting the fires.

"We are confident that the Commonwealth War Graves Commission, local authorities and firefighters will do all they can to protect and rehabilitate the sacred sites and monuments, but we understand that the situation is serious and remain concerned," he said.

Türkiye's Minister of Agriculture and Forestry İbrahim Yumaklı said the fire — sparked by an electricity pole — had now been contained.

Mr Yumaklı said 1,413 firefighters — supported by 14 planes, 31 helicopters and 265 land vehicles — had been dispatched to control another fire in Manisa, 300 kilometres from the Gallipoli site.

He warned of a high risk of wildfires in the next three days due to high temperatures, low humidity and strong winds.

Two wildfires remain out of control across Türkiye, with Mr Karacabey reporting a "superhuman effort" to douse a blaze in the Bolu province.

The governors of Canakkale and Bolu provinces said several neighbourhoods or villages had been evacuated as a precaution, but that there was no immediate threat to residential areas.

A forest fire in Turkey's western coastal province of Izmir has been fanned by strong winds towards residential areas, forcing evacuations, the local governor said on Friday.

The fire in Izmir started late on Thursday in the Karsiyaka district for unknown reasons.

Izmir Governor Suleyman Elban said the fire raged between four and five different areas despite efforts to contain it using planes, helicopters and other vehicles.

"The intervention is becoming difficult as it is very close to residential areas. There is no loss of life until now," he said.

"We have information that some houses burned. Since there are winds of up to 80 kilometres per hour now, we often have to stop the aerial intervention."

urn:contentItem:6DR0-R2X3-RSMJ-X1F1-00000-00What does the Boxing Day forecast mean for the fires?2024-12-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:24ZLexisNexisWhat does the Boxing Day forecast mean for the fires?

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Three bushfires are currently burning out of control across the state, with emergency authorities warning soaring temperatures on Boxing Day could be "catastrophic".

"Boxing Day is going to be problematic. Boxing Day is going to be a big day for our state," Deputy Premier Ben Carroll said on Monday.

"The advice is very clear. This is the beginning of what will be a long, hot and dangerous bushfire season.

"The fire that we don't know about is the fire we are worried about."

Emergency Management Commissioner Rick Nugent said there are currently three fires burning out of control across Victoria.

There are fears the fire at the Grampians in the state's west, which has so far burnt through 40,000 hectares of land, will spread "rapidly" on Thursday.

Eighteen fire bombing aircraft's and 300 firefighters are working to control that blaze.

Firefighters are also working to build a perimeter around a fire at The Gurdies, in South Gippsland, which has already burnt through 200 hectares.

"That fire has enormous potential to grow on Thursday," Forest Fire Management chief fire officer Chris Hardman said.

West of Gisborne, another fire is burning out of control which authorities fear could spread into the northern suburbs of Ballarat.

"There is a power of work being done to control that fire," Mr Hardman added.

CFA chief officer Jason Heffernan said it wouldn't be uncommon for power outages and loss of internet on Boxing Day.

Mr Heffernan said Victorians couldn't afford to be complacent on Boxing Day.

He said people needed to download the VicEmergency app on their phone.

"Every Victorian needs to have that app on their phone and on them on Boxing Day," he said.

Emergency Services Minister Vicki Ward urged Victorians to not travel unnecessarily on Boxing Day.

"We need you to be safe," she said.

"Please take this seriously."

What emergency warnings are in place?

VicEmergency issued an evacuation order on Monday for residents in Bellfield, Bellfield Settlement, Flat Rock Crossing, Fyans Creek, Grampians Junction and Halls Gap.

The bushfire, at Grampians National Park on Yarram Gap Rd, is still raging across the area, moving in a northerly direction towards Halls Gap.

The warning said the blaze had reached Lake Bellfield.

The emergency service issued a "watch and act" warning for residents in Barton, Mafeking, Watgania, Lake Fyans, Pomonal, Bellellen, Black Range, Great Western, Jallukar, Lake Fyans, Londonderry, Moyston, Rhymney and Willaura North.

Residents in Fyans Creek, Lake Lonsdale, Ledcourt, Mokepilly, Mount Dryde, Wartook, Zumsteins, Bornes Hill, Grampians, Jimmy Creek, Mirranatwa, Victoria Valley, Kia Ora and Willaura were being urged to "stay informed"

There are two relief centres open - in Ararat at the Alexandra Oval Community Centre and in Stawell at the Grampians Community Health.

How long is it expected to last?

Victorians in the area have been urged to stay alert on Boxing Day as scorching temperatures are expected to intensify the dangerous bushfire.

"Milder conditions overnight have seen a reduction in fire activity (in the Grampians) however the situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act," VicEmergency said on Monday.

"Hotter and windier conditions are forecast for Christmas Day and Boxing Day. Plan accordingly."

More than 300 firefighters are currently battling the blaze, with the Victorian Country Fire Authority warning it could take weeks to put out the fire.

In Melbourne, temperatures are forecast to reach 30C on Christmas Day and 40C on Boxing Day.

It will be hotter in regional areas of the state, with Stawell and Ararat expected to reach 35C on Christmas Day and 40C on Boxing Day, and Horsham tipping past 42C on Thursday.

Most of Victoria has been issued a high fire danger warning on Monday morning, with residents in Mallee, Northern Country, Wimmera, North Central, North East, Central and South West.

Residents in Melbourne have also been advised to take extra caution as temperatures increase over the week.

A "catastrophic" fire danger will be issued for Wimmera on Thursday, while Mallee, Northern Country, North Central, Central, and South West regions will be issued with extreme fire danger.

A high fire danger will be in effect for residents in North East, East, West and South Gippsland.

"Boxing Day is a big travel day right across the state, so we urge those travelling to download the VicEmergency app before you go," Victorian Country Fire Authority's deputy chief officer Garry Cook said.

Can I travel to the Grampians?

Mr Heffernan said it was not safe to travel near the Grampians.

He urged people to reconsider their travel plans.

Emergency services warn the current situation is dynamic.

"There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes," it said.

VicEmergency urged residents to monitor weather conditions and warnings and review their fire survival plan.

They warned nearby areas will be impacted by smoke and road closures.

"Bushfires can spread quickly and are extremely dangerous," they said.

"Trees can be extremely dangerous during a bushfire or high winds. Do not stand, park or travel in areas of fire affected trees."

I have a booking nearby, what should I do?

Travellers should contact their booking provider and accommodation services for further assistance.

The Grampians National Park is closed to visitors. Further information can be found on the Parks Victoria website.

urn:contentItem:6DPJ-TH53-RRH5-645B-00000-00More than 300 firefighters work to contain Grampians National Park bushfire2024-12-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:24ZLexisNexisMore than 300 firefighters work to contain Grampians National Park bushfireBen Fraser

Strong southerly winds push Grampians bushfire towards Halls Gap.

Update 8.20pm: Authorities have provided an update on the bushfire as they work to contain it overnight.

The Grampians National Park bushfire is now 29,000 hectares in size with a fire perimeter of 192km.

More than 300 firefighters from Forest Fire Management Victoria, CFA and Fire Rescue Victoria are on the ground and at least another 100 remain in the Incident Control Centre in Horsham.

The warning for Pomonal and Lake Fyans residents to leave is now downgraded, but it is strongly recommended that those remaining in the area be prepared to leave.

Residents should monitor the situation as an increase in wind speed, a change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can mean the situation is worsening.

Communities near Wartook are advised to be vigilant conditions move the firefront along the eastern wall.

Almost 31,000ha has been burnt since December 17.

Update 4pm: State Control Centre spokesperson Luke Hegarty reiterated the advice for people in the Bellfield, Fyans Creek and Halls Gap areas.

"The advice there is to evacuate immediately," he said.

"There are relief centres established at Ararat and Stawell.

"There are also other emergency warnings associated with the Grampians fire with advice to leave immediately for Lake Fyans, Pomonal, Watgania and Mafeking."

Mr Hegarty said all of these warnings are on the VicEmergency app and the VicEmergency website.

"If you're travelling over the next few days, it's really important that before you start your travel, to check the Vic emergency app, the Vic emergency website, or call the Vic emergency hotline on 1800226226, and listen to emergency broadcasters such as ABC local Radio."

Update 4pm: State Control Centre spokesperson Luke Hegarty reiterated the advice for people in the Bellfield, Fyans Creek and Halls Gap areas.

"The advice there is to evacuate immediately," he said.

"There are relief centres established at Ararat and Stawell.

"There are also other emergency warnings associated with the Grampians fire with advice to leave immediately for Lake Fyans, Pomonal, Watgania and Mafeking."

Mr Hegarty said all of these warnings are on the VicEmergency app and the VicEmergency website.

"If you're travelling over the next few days, it's really important that before you start your travel, to check the Vic emergency app, the Vic emergency website, or call the Vic emergency hotline on 1800226226, and listen to emergency broadcasters such as ABC local Radio."

Update 3pm: If you are located in Bellfield, Bellfield Settlement, Flat Rock Crossing, Fyans Creek, Grampians Junction or Halls Gap, it is recommended you evacuate immediately and move to a safer location away from the fire.

Recordings of Community meetings are available from https://www.facebook.com/VicEmergencyGrampians .

Update 12pm: Residents of Halls Gap, Bellfield, Bellfield Settlement, Flat Rock Crossing and Fyans Creek have been told to leave immediately.

The bushfire has reached Lake Bellfield and the Major Mitchell Plateau, and is moving in a northerly direction towards Halls Gap.

Crews and aircraft continue to work in the area; backburning operations will be conducted today and smoke will be visible.

A second relief centre has opened as more people leave the bushfire-affected Grampians National Park.

Grampians Community Health opened its doors at 22 Patrick Street Stawell.

Alexandra Oval Community Centre relief centre remains open at 1 Waratah Avenue.

Emergency services issued a warning to residents of Barton, Jallukur and Londonderry.

Earlier: The Grampians National Park bushfire is edging closer to Halls Gap and Pomonal as the bushfire triples in size.

Holidaymakers were urged to leave the Grampians as firefighters battled the 28,100 ha blaze on multiple fronts.

The main front travelled north towards Halls Gap as southerly winds pushed the bushfire closer to the popular holiday destination.

Parks Victoria closed the Grampians National Park and urged travellers to use the Alexandra Oval Community Centre relief centre at 1 Waratah Avenue.

During the community meeting in Ararat, Emergency Management Victoria controller Mark Gunning said Pomonal was not under direct threat.

"We have strike teams ... who are extremely effective in suppressing fires," he said.

Overnight the fire crossed Redman Road and travelled in two directions as it burned around Lake Belfield.

Another front is travelling northerly direction towards Mt William.

Backburning operations will be conducted today, and smoke will be visible.

Residents of Moyston, Barton, Jallukur and Willaura are being warned to stay on high alert as another front slowly moves east.

Community meetings planned for Pomonal and Halls Gap have been relocated.

The first meeting at the Ararat Town Hall at 10am provided an update on the Grampians bushfire. It was live-streamed on the Ararat Rural City Council Facebook page.

An additional community meeting was held in Stawell Town Hall at 11.30am and was Northern Grampians Shire Council Facebook page.

Check the VicTraffic website for road closures.

The blaze comes just 10 months after the catastrophic Pomonal bushfire that destroyed 44 homes on February 13.
